facts.front: What are the main distributions of Linux today?
facts.back:
- Debian based
	- **Debian** (1993)
		- popular in server space
		- two package managers, apt and aptitude
			- apt was part of Debian’s .deb package; however, it was updated to work with the RPM Package Manager.
			- aptitude is a front-end tool
		- dpkg [DEE-package]
	- **Ubuntu** (2003)
		- most popular Linux distribution today
		- uses apt package manager
		- has a lot more drivers than Debian
		- Debian and Ubuntu are similar
			- Debian more of a server distribution
			- Ubuntu more of a personal laptop distribution
	- **Mint** (2006)
		- based on Ubuntu
		- started out with pre-installed multimedia codecs and proprietary drivers
		- good for beginners
	- *elementary OS* (2011)
		- promotes itself as a "thoughtful, capable, and ethical" replacement to macOS and Windows and has a pay-what-you-want model
		- desktop environment: Pantheon
	- *Kali* (2013)
		- designed for digital forensics and penetration testing
		- primary tool used by ethical hackers
		- allows you to test networks to see if they're vulnerable to outside attacks
- RPM based
	- **RedHat** (1995)
		- known as RHEL (RedHat Enterprise Linux)
		- created the rpm package format 
		- uses yum
			- RPM is autonomous and utilizes its own database to keep information about the packages on the system
			- YUM is a front-end utility that uses the RPM package manager for package management
	- **Fedora** (2003)
		- uses newer technology and packages from the open source world than RHEL
		- uses yum package manager as does RHEL
		- Fedora releases often while CentOS is more stable
		- **suited for workstation applications and non-production servers**
		- every six months a version like Ubuntu
		- DNF package manager
	- **CentOS** (2004)
		- functionally compatible with RHEL	
		- focuses on the stability and robustness
		- used when you need a more stable system that requires the RHEL’s feature set
		- its successor is Rocky Linux
		- on CentOS you'll find older packages, on Fedora, typically new ones
		- **on December 8, 2020, Red Hat announced that development of CentOS Linux would be discontinued**
	- *Suse Linux* (1994)
		- known for its YaST configuration tool
		- known for the KDE desktop and stability
		- for package management uses zypper and its graphical fronted, the Yast software center
		- 2003 Novell bought Suse
		- 2005 the openSUSE Project
			- Zypper package manager
		- **over time, SuSE Linux incorporated many aspects of Red Hat Linux, such as its RPM Package Manager and its file structure**
	- **Rocky Linux** (2021)
		- complete binary-compatible release using the Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) operating system source code
		- aim is to provide a community-supported, production-grade enterprise operating
		- Rocky Linux is considered the unofficial successor to CentOS, a fork of RHEL
		- Rocky Linux has no corporate backing, while Alma is controlled by the CloudLinux people
	- *AlmaLinux* (2021)
		- AlmaLinux and Rocky Linux are the two brightest shining stars since CentOS ceded its position as a reliable RHEL-based server operating system
		- nonprofit
		- first version February 2021
		- totally compatible with RedHat
- other distributions
	- *Slackware* (1992)
		- oldest Linux distribution in use today
		- does not have a package manager and all the software is compiled by the system administrator or normal users of the system
		- packages are simply source code
		- if you really want to learn a lot about how Linux really works, use Slackware
	- *FreeBSD* (1993)
		- offered at DigitalOcean
		- FreeBSD has similarities with Linux, with two major differences in scope and licensing: FreeBSD maintains a complete system, i.e. the project delivers a kernel, device drivers, userland utilities, and documentation, as opposed to Linux only delivering a kernel and drivers, and relying on third-parties for system software
		- pkg package management system
		- much of FreeBSD's codebase has become an integral part of other operating systems such as Darwin (the basis for macOS)
			- and the system software for the PlayStation 
	- *Gentoo* (2002)
		- based on the portage package management system
		- can be difficult to install 
			- advantage of such an approach is that the software is built for the specific hardware that it will be running on
	- **Arch** (2002)
		- default installation is a minimal base system, configured by the user to only add what is purposely required
		- uses pkg.tar.xz packages and has it's own **package manager called pacman**
		- does not come with a graphical installer and the whole installation process is done via a terminal
		- main philosophy behind Arch is KISS 
		- makes few assumptions about how you want your system to be configured
			- Arch starts form a very neutral place
			- this makes the installation process confusing
		- has rolling release so there are no large versions
		- uses systemd system management framework
		- installation
			- can choose template, e.g. server or desktop
			- go to https://archlinux.org/download
			- download image
			- virtual box
			- it immediatly goes to root user
			- `archinstall` is easier
			- asks many questions, e.g. file system: ext4
			- leave root password blank to disable account
			- provide name for superuser account
			- choose desktop
			- linux kernel
			- poweroff
		- using after installation
			- `sudo pacman -Syu` = update system
			- you can install groups: https://archlinux.org/groups
		- see the [Wiki entry for principles](https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Arch_Linux#Principles)
		- targeted at power users
	- *Alpine* (2005)
		- designed to be small, simple and secure
		- uses musl and BusyBox instead of the more commonly used Glibc and GNU Core Utilities
		- because of its small size, it is commonly used in containers providing quick boot-up times
	- *Manjaro* (2011)
		- based on the Arch Linux operating system that has a focus on user-friendliness 
		- uses Pacman
		- developed mainly in Austria, France and Germany
		- easier to use
	- *EndeavourOS* (2019)
		- based on Arch Linux
		- seen as a workstation
		- features the graphical Calamares installer capable of installing the Xfce, Budgie, Cinnamon, GNOME, i3, KDE Plasma 5, LXQt, and MATE desktop environments
		- not as mature as other distributions

facts.front: What is Git?
facts.back: Git is a **distributed version control system** that tracks changes in computer files, for either **single-user projects** or more commonly for **teams of programmers** to **collaboratively develop** code during **software development**

facts.front: Who created Git, when and why?
facts.back:
- **Linus Torvalds** created Git in **2005** because the version control system he was using (BitKeeper) for his Linux kernal project was inadequate
	- BitKeeper had liscening terms such that it wasn't completely free for the Linux team to use it for their purposes
- so Linus created his own version control system which was free and open source, called **Git**

facts.front: What were the main design requirements for Git?
facts.back:
- completely **free and open source** (unlike BitKeeper)
- **fast and flexible**
- **decentralized** - no main repository
	- every developer has the complete repository on their computer
	- e.g. the repository of our course website at GitHub is the same as each of the repositories on our machines
	- this wasn't true for e.g. Subversion (SVN) which has a main repository which is the source of truth for the data, while developers check out copies of this
- **can handle large projects** like the Linux kernel

facts.front: What are some alternative version control systems besides Git?
facts.back:
- there really are no serious competitors to Git anymore
	- **CVS** - very old, I remember it from the 90s, the first versioning software I used, centralized and simple, development on this project stopped in 2008
	- **SVN** - old, we used this in projects up until 2013, 2014, is now an Apache project and seems to be still developed and used but is increasingly unpopular
	- **Mercurial** - similar to Git, one hears about it but I have never used it
		- *"even though Mercurial may be easier to learn and use, its branching model often creates confusion"*
	- **Team Foundation Server** - Microsoft's solution, although Git is also commonly used in Microsoft/.NET-based projects
- Git has become the absolute standard for software development versioning software

facts.front: What does Git store in its repository?
facts.back: Basically, Git stores snapshots of how your files looked at specific times in the past. It stores your initial **files**, plus the **differences** between the files (deltas), and **who** changed those files and **when**.

facts.front: What command do you need to execute before `commit -m "created login page"`?

instructionItems.title: Different ways to use Git, GitHub and Git branching
instructionItems.body:
- **1. GitHub Classroom**
	- you push directly to default directory
	- Code Buddy is installed to check your work automatically
	- branching is not used or needed in this use-case of Git and GitHub
- **2. team projects** - numerous developers
	- this is what Git and GitHub are mostly used for in companies and open source developer teams
	- this is the reason Linus created Git: to manage code in large projects of many developers
	- our course website is an example of this, which gives you experience of working in project teams
		- you have to work in an organized fashion to avoid chaos and conflicts
			- a developer team has a project board like we have: [WD23-D04 Project Board](https://github.com/orgs/WD23-D04/projects/1/views/1?visibleFields=%5B%22Title%22%2C%22Assignees%22%2C%22Status%22%2C%22Labels%22%5D)
		- you check out tasks, then accomplish them
			- you create a **task branch**
			- when finished you create a **pull request**
			- you **merge** your pull request into the dev branch
				- if there are conflicts, you **resolve the conflicts**
			- the main work flow is described here: http://localhost:3500/documentation
		- there is one more step which we don't use yet in our course website and repository: **deployment**
			- if our website was being published online
			- we would have a main branch as well
			- we would develop our site by working on task branches which we merge into dev
			- as a team, we would have e.g. two-week **sprints** in which we have a specific collection of tasks to accomplish
			- at the end of the sprint when all tasks are accomplished and tested in dev, the repository manager would locally merge **dev** into **main**, then push main to the GitHub repository
			- this would trigger DevOps processes which then pull the changes and push them to the live servers
		- there can be another step before deployment called **testing**
			- the repository manager merges **dev** into **testing** and pushes this to the repository
			- this triggers DevOps processes which push the changes to testing servers that are online
				- automatic end-to-end tests are performed on the live data
				- manual tests are performed: you can use the site live with smart phones etc.
			- then when all tests pass, the repository managers merges the **testing branch** into the **main branch** and pushes it to the GitHub repository so it gets deployed live
		- there are many variations on this workflow and various philosophies of how teams should work with GitHub
			- each company and team has a slightly different process
			- but you find these basic concepts in all workflows:
				- dev
				- testing
				- main

facts.front: What is the difference between a commit and a push?
facts.back:
- A **commit** is a snapshot of changes made to a repository's files. This is often done locally even when one doesn't have a GitHub repository for the local repository. It's useful to simply have certain points in a code's history that you can go back to and observe how it worked at that point, etc.
- A **push** is the act of uploading the committed changes from your local Git repository to a remote repository, typically GitHub.

facts.front: What command would a developer use to create a branch to work on a new project feature?
facts.back:
The command `git checkout -b` creates a new branch. So according to the conventions we use in our course website project, if Edward creates a feature branch to add a page called *Tech Podcasts*, he might use the command:
`git checkout -b edward-create-page-tech-podcasts`

facts.front: What is the difference between a respository and a branch?
facts.back:
A **repository** is a collection of files, folders, and version history, along with the necessary metadata for Git to track changes and manage versions.
A **branch** is a pointer to a specific version of the codebase within a repository. Developers typically create a branch to work on a feature away from the dev branch. When the feature branch is finished, it is pushed to repository at GitHub, a pull-request is made, that pull-request is then merged into the dev branch to become part of the code that all developers are working on.
When the dev branch has all features for a version merged and tested, then its changes are merged into the main branch, which is then pushed to the web for deployment.

facts.front: If you are working in a feature branch e.g. `edward-create-login-page` and want to switch back to the `dev` branch, what Git command would you use?
facts.back: `git checkout dev`

facts.front: What does merging allow you to do?
facts.back: Merging allows you to combine changes made on one branch with the changes on a different branch.

facts.front: What two commands would you use to merge the changes in the `dev` branch into the `main` so that the changes get published as a new version?
facts.back:
`git checkout main`
`git merge dev`

facts.front: Is Git the same as GitHub?
facts.back: No, Git is a distributed version control system that allows multiple developers in a team to create Git repositories to manage their code changes over time. GitHub is a web-based platform that provides a graphical interface for working with Git repositories. GitHub is a host for online Git repositories.

facts.front: Who owns Git and GitHub?
facts.back: Git is a free and open-source distributed version control system created by Linus Torvalds in 2005. GitHub was created in 2008 by Chris Wanstrath and others. In 2018, Microsoft aquired GitHub for $7.5 billion, so Microsoft owns GitHub but Git remains an open-source project maintained by a community of developers.

facts.front: Is GitHub only used for open-source projects?
facts.back: No, but it is very popular with open-source projects because of its generous free tier.

facts.front: In a GitHub repository that has numerous branches and you clone it to your local machine, how many of the branches to you have access to on your local machine?
facts.back: All of them.

learnItems.title: Use the browser Dev Tools to debug your HTML/CSS website by viewing and manipulating the DOM tree
learnItems.body:
- the DOM tree is the collection of nested elements that one sees in the browser dev tools inspector
- the DOM (Document Object Model) of your page can be navigated by opening and closing the elements that are nested within each other
- the tree is also editable, so you can delete nodes, change the text and the nodes, etc.
	- the terms **node**, **element** and **tag** are often used interchangably
	- we speak of elements as **nodes** when we are talking about the nested elements in a DOM tree
	- and remember: an **element** such as a **div** technically has two **tags**, an opening **tag** and a closing **tag**
	- and no: a **node** in the DOM tree has nothing to do with Node/Express on the backend :-)
		- regularly refer back to [the big picture](https://coggle.it/diagram/ZE-oXwAjwnrf-l8P/t/web-development) of web development
	- trouble shooting: if the inspector doesn't work, you probably need to reload your (1) Live Server, (2) Vite server (Vanilla), or (3) Vite server (React)
		- if you are working on a HTML/CSS/JavaScript site that a browser is displaying, then inspector will always work, there is no server in this case
	- you delete nodes with the **Delete** button
		- see what your site would look like with one fewer div
	- you can edit node text with **double-click**
		- you can edit anything in the HTML, e.g. replace text to see if longer words will fit:##changebrowsertext
	- you can add elements with **right-click, edit HTML**
